access to frequent transit.name: access to frequent transit
access to frequent transit.notes:
research indicates that passengers are willing to walk 400 meters to access basic transit services and up to 800 meters to access rapid transit services. translink's frequent transit network provides all day service at frequencies of every 15 minutes or better. this indicator tracks the percentage of surrey's population that lives within 400 meters of a frequent transit network bus stop or within 800 meters of a skytrain station. this is a measure of how convenient and useful transit is to the residents of surrey.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#built_environment/proximity_transit).

active traffic obstructions.notes: this api is surrey’s implementation of the open511 specification. it provides information about known road events (special events, construction, etc.). to view active real-time traffic obstructions on a map, please see the [open511 roadcast](https://data.surrey.ca/open511/map/).

groups.description: the transportation department provides transportation options in surrey regarding driving, cycling, walking, taking transit or finding a new smarter travel choice. surrey's [transportation strategic plan] (http://www.surrey.ca/city-services/4789.aspx) shows the vision, goals, proposals and priorities for transportation in the city.
groups.name: transportation

active transportation infrastructure.name: active transportation infrastructure
active transportation infrastructure.notes:
greenways, pathways, and separated bicycle lanes provide convenient and safe connections throughout the city.  as active transportation routes, they complement existing infrastructure such as sidewalks, and provide opportunities for walking, running and cycling for leisure or commuting. the presence of pathways and cycling routes that connect to services and amenities is an important feature in encouraging residents to walk and cycle. the length of greenways, pathways and separated bike lanes is a measure of how liveable and complete surrey's neighbourhoods are, and the city aims to see an upward trend over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/trails).

age of buildings.name: age of buildings
age of buildings.notes:
the age of buildings is an approximate estimate of building quality. while older developments facilitate mixed uses and are important pieces of local history, they also tend to have more problems. older buildings usually have more maintenance issues and can pose health hazards, such as asbestos and lead-based paint, due to years of poor maintenance. the median age of buildings by neighbourhood is a measure of the quality of existing development in surrey.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#energysystems/ageofbuildings)

air quality.name: air quality
air quality.notes:
the air we breathe affects human health, the environment, and our quality of life. air quality is determined by the level of pollutants suspended in the air, as well as weather conditions and local topography. fine particulate matter is 2.5 microns or less in diameter (pm2.5), which is about 1/30th the width of a human hair. pm2.5 is especially damaging because it can penetrate into our lungs and bloodstream, increasing the risk of cancer, aggravating lung and heart diseases, and reducing life expectancy. the largest emitters of fine particulate matter in the lower mainland are wood burning fireplaces, industry, and engine exhaust. metro vancouver is responsible for monitoring air quality in the region, and aims to have air quality meet or exceed standards at all times.

for this and other sustainability indicators, see the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#ecosystems/air_quality)

real-time air quality and weather data is displayed from the lower fraser valley air quality monitoring network in southwestern british columbia, canada. metro vancouver operates this network in cooperation with the fraser valley regional district, environment canada and other partners.

###link to metro vancouver airmap site:

###[surrey air quality](https://gis.metrovancouver.org/maps/air)

once you have opened the above link, click on __surrey east__ station

aquatic hubs.name: aquatic hubs
aquatic hubs.notes: aquatic hubs are large contiguous or near contiguous areas of streams, wetlands, and foreshore areas, within or immediately adjacent to surrey with complex ecological processes identified in the surrey ecosystem management study (ems) that are at least 10 inches size.

groups.description: each community offers a diverse range of recreational spaces including gymnasiums, preschool sites, fitness studios, weight rooms, pools and outdoor spaces. the city of surrey offers registered and drop-in recreational activities to keep its residents healthy, active and engaged.
groups.name: recreation-and-culture

arts and culture groups.name: arts and culture groups
arts and culture groups.notes:
cultural activities are recognized as an important way for individuals to contribute to their communities. culture is an essential tool in understanding the values, shared meanings, and goals of residents within a community. arts and culture related groups provide services such as sponsoring and producing community events and other learning opportunities. the number of arts and culture related groups that are registered with the surrey arts council is a measure of the availability of cultural opportunities and services. data source: surrey arts council.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/artsgroups).

groups.description: the city of surrey is responsible for the encouragement, regulation and enforcement of workplace health, safety and welfare. residents and families are encouraged to maintain an active and healthy lifestyle and have the ability to attend both registered and drop-in programs.
groups.name: health-and-safety

availability of doctors.name: availability of doctors
availability of doctors.notes:
health care professionals provide services such as diagnosis, treatment, and care. primary health care professionals, such as general practitioners and nurses, are especially important because they are often the first points of contact for someone with a health care concern and can play a significant role in helping patients to maintain good health and prevent illnesses. the availability of health care providers is a measure of how accessible the health care system is. the city aims to have the number of doctors per 100,000 residents on par with other major urban centres in the province. data source: canadian institute for health information.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_wellness/doctors).

groups.description: the economic development and sustainability office collect and analyze information to make investment decisions, encourage business growth and create municipal economic policy. such information include economic indicators, business licensing statistics, demographic profiles and building permits.
groups.name: business-and-economy

availability of employment.name: availability of employment
availability of employment.notes:
the availability of locally-based employment opportunities provide social benefits by creating more complete communities where residents can spend less time commuting and more time with their families and participating in their community. it also reduces the environmental costs of commuting. the ratio of jobs to workers is a measure of how well the city is doing in expanding and diversifying local employment opportunities.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/jobs)

groups.description: the city of surrey has a comprehensive set of plans, policies and regulations to guide future development. land use plans determine the location and type of development and policies and strategies provide a framework for the development of surrey. development projects that comply with these guidelines and requirements help the city grow and meet sustainability objectives.
groups.name: land-use-and-development

available farmland in the alr.name: available farmland in the alr
available farmland in the alr.notes:
in 1973, the provincial government established  the agricultural land reserve (alr) to protect quality farmland.   although land in the alr is protected, non-farming uses, such as golf courses, parkland, utilities, and industrial space can encroach on farmland. the percentage of surrey's alr that is available for farming is a measure of how well farmland is being maintained, and it is the city's policy to see no net loss in agricultural land over time. data source: bc ministry of agriculture.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/alr).

groups.name: business-and-economy

average home price.name: average home price
average home price.notes:
home ownership offers many advantages. it provides some financial security in the form of capital appreciation when housing prices increase. owning a home can be a stable way of meeting housing needs. however, home ownership can also generate financial stress by demanding a large proportion of a household's income. home maintenance also requires time and money. the average price of a house in surrey is a measure of housing and home ownership affordability. data source: fraser valley real estate board.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#housing/averagehomeprice).

biodiversity conservation strategy.name: biodiversity conservation strategy
biodiversity conservation strategy.notes:
the [biodiversity conservation strategy](http://www.surrey.ca/files/surrey_bcs_report.pdf) (bcs), adopted in 2014 as part of corporate report [r141](http://www.surrey.ca/bylawsandcouncillibrary/cr_2014-r141.pdf), recognizes surrey’s biodiversity as a key foundation of a healthy, livable and sustainable city. the goal of the strategy is to preserve, protect, and enhance surrey’s biodiversity.

the dataset consists of the green infrastructure network corridors, green infrastructure network hubs and sites and habitat suitability.

habitat suitability mapping is based on work completed for the 2011 surrey [ecosystem management study](http://www.surrey.ca/city-services/1332.aspx) and terrestrial ecosystem mapping data and incorporated information from the environmentally sensitive areas ("esa") map and other relevant data sources based on species at risk presence, species accounts and known ecosystem habitat inventories. this map identifies the most biologically diverse habitats across the city in a comparative analysis from highest value to lower values.

a green infrastructure network ("gin") is an interconnected system of natural areas and open space that conserves ecosystems and functions, while providing benefits to both wildlife and people.  the surrey gin identifies that approximately 10,200 acres (4,130 hectares) of land are required to maintain the city’s biodiversity.

for more information please see the city of surrey [biodiversity conservation strategy] (http://www.surrey.ca/city-services/11565.aspx) page.

building permits.name: building permits
building permits.notes:
surrey issues building permits to ensure that construction complies with the bc building code as well as the city's own policies and regulations. information gathered from building permit applications provide insights into demographic changes and development activity. it is also used to calibrate the city's population estimates. information is available on current building permit activity as well as [building permit activity for previous years.](http://www.surrey.ca/city-services/16818.aspx)

detailed building permit summaries are prepared each month. they provide monthly and current year cumulative information on the number of permits issued, the number of dwellings being built, and the value of the permits. the summaries also provide comparable information from the previous year.

bulk data.name: bulk data
bulk data.notes: high resolution orthophoto, lidar, and other remote sensing data are available for the whole city via the city’s bulk data download service.  due to the large size of these data, data of this nature in their entirety is not available for download via the city’s open data catalog.  to obtain a copy of these data, complete and send the [citywide data request form](http://cosmos.surrey.ca/geo_ref/images/opendataarchives/citywide_data_request_form.pdf) to gis@surrey.ca.  a list of available datasets included in the bulk data download service can be found here: [cos remote sensing data inventory](http://cosmos.surrey.ca/geo_ref/images/opendataarchives/cos_remote_sensing_data_inventory.pdf). this service is provided free of charge. a target turnaround of 1 week is anticipated. however, the time may be extended during peak periods. please note that you must supply the city with an external hard drive with a storage capacity of at least 1tb supporting usb 3.0. the city of surrey does not cover shipping costs. you may arrange a courier to deliver and pick up your portable hard drive or you can drop off and pick up on your own.

car ownership.name: car ownership
car ownership.notes:
driving a vehicle consumes more fuel and emits more greenhouse gases than other modes of transportation such as taking transit, biking, and walking. there is a clear link between car ownership and car use, and increases in car ownership are likely to create more air, noise, and water pollution, greater consumption of land for transport, and less compact and complete communities. the city aims to see car ownership trend down over time. data source: insurance corporation of bc.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#transportation/carownership).

certified green buildings.name: certified green buildings
certified green buildings.notes:
green buildings use energy, water and other resources more efficiently, reduce waste and pollution, and protect occupant health. green building certification systems set voluntary standards for industry to incorporate features that are environmentally responsible and resource efficient. these practices extend to many aspects of a building's life cycle, including siting, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and renovation. the number of new buildings in surrey that are certified as green is a measure of how sustainable the built environment is. data sources: canadian green building council, canadian home builders association.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#energysystems/greenbuildings).

groups.description: the city of surrey is committed to protecting and enhancing natural and environmentally sensitive areas from harmful development. policies and regulations with respect to environmentally sensitive development are contained in city plans and by-laws as well as in provincial and federal acts.
groups.name: environment

certified green buildings existing.name: certified green buildings existing
certified green buildings existing.notes:
buildings account for a significant proportion of energy use and greenhouse gas (ghg) emissions in a community. green building certification systems set voluntary standards for industry to incorporate features that are environmentally responsible and resource efficient. certification can encourage building managers to undertake energy retrofits and maintain energy efficient building practices, which can also result in energy savings and reduced ghg emissions. the number of existing buildings that achieve green certification is a measure of the energy and environmental performance of surrey's building stock. data source: boma best.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#energysystems/energyretrofits).

child poverty.name: child poverty
child poverty.notes:
children and families with low income have inadequate resources to support their basic needs such as food, housing,  and transportation. children living in poverty are more likely to struggle in school, suffer from health issues, experience behavioural problems or bullying, and access fewer developmental opportunities. child poverty is a measure of surrey's social well-being and the city aims to see a downward trend over time. (note: in 2005 statistics canada reported income status using the low income cut-off (lico) measure, whereas in 2010 income status was reported using the low income measure (lim). while both measures are indicators of poverty the two cannot be directly compared.)

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/lowincome).

city cultural grants.name: city cultural grants
city cultural grants.notes:
the cultural grants program supports the development of local arts and heritage organizations, and aims to stimulate new programs and activities that will make surrey a cultural destination. a vibrant cultural sector promotes civic pride and placemaking, and can facilitate a shared understanding of values amongst surrey's diverse population. investing in arts and heritage through surrey's cultural grants program is an important step towards creating a thriving and inclusive world class city.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/cultural_grants).

city funding for beautification.name: city funding for beautification
city funding for beautification.notes:
civic beautification involves the creation and maintenance of landscaping, gardening, and public art features by the city and its residents. it contributes to liveability, enriches public spaces and promotes community spirit and pride. civic beautification projects are also opportunities for community involvement where residents of all ages, community groups, service clubs and businesses can take ownership of their community. funding for civic beautification is a measure of the liveability and quality of the built environment, and the city aims to see an upward trend over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#growth/beautification)

city spending on public art.name: city spending on public art
city spending on public art.notes:
public art is any work of art or design that is created specifically for a public space. public art pieces are components of a community's identity and unique character. they also express community values, increase awareness, enhance the landscape, and transform a city's image. city spending on public art is a measure of how well funded public art is in surrey.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/publicart)

groups.description: the finance department provides financial expertise, advice and guidance to support city operations. they provide responsive service to their clients, leadership in improving city processes and maintain financial practices, policies and standards while supporting the city's sustainability charter.
groups.name: finance

city tax base.name: city tax base
city tax base.notes:
property taxes are one of the most important sources of revenue for the city and fund many services and programs essential for residents and businesses. the proportions of the tax base that are residential, business and industry is a measure of how balanced the city's tax base is. the city's target is to have 60% of the tax base from residential properties, and 40% from commercial and industrial properties by 2021.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/taxbase).

groups.description: a local council authority that provides local services, facilities, safety and infrastructure for communities. while the municipality has autonomy on most decisions, all by-laws passed are subject to change by the provincial government at any time.
groups.name: local-government

city volunteers.name: city volunteers
city volunteers.notes:
volunteering is the offering of one's time, energy and skill, often without monetary reward. volunteering gives residents opportunities to become involved in their communities, help others, accomplish activities and provide services that may not otherwise exist. volunteers also benefit from gaining new skills, meeting new people, and feeling a sense of belonging and empowerment. the number of residents that volunteer with the city is a measure of the level of volunteerism in surrey, and the city aims to see a 2% increase in volunteerism per year.

for this and other sustainability indicators, see the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/cityvolunteers)

community gardens.name: community gardens
community gardens.notes:
community gardens enhance community food security by allowing urban residents to grow their own food. community gardens offer health benefits by providing people with access to fresh produce and regular activity. they can also be a significant source of food for low-income community members. community gardens are places where people can learn about environmental stewardship and meet neighbours. this indicator is a measure of how accessible urban agriculture, and the city aims to see the number of plots trend up over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_wellness/communitygardens).

community ghg emissions.name: community ghg emissions
community ghg emissions.notes:
buildings and transportation are two major sources of community greenhouse gas emissions that can have far-reaching and unpredictable environmental and economic consequences. ghg emissions can be reduced in part by limiting energy consumption. retrofits of existing buildings, construction of new more efficient buildings, greener commercial fleets using more energy-efficient technologies, and the promotion of active and alternative transportation contribute to creating fewer ghg emissions as well as saving money. the city's target is to reduce per capita ghg emissions by 33% by 2020 and by 80% by 2050.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/community_ghg).

groups.description: the city of surrey is committed to protecting and enhancing natural and environmentally sensitive areas from harmful development. policies and regulations with respect to environmentally sensitive development are contained in city plans and by-laws as well as in provincial and federal acts.
groups.name: environment

community waste.name: community waste
community waste.notes:
diverting waste extends the life of landfills by reducing the volume of garbage, and reduces the greenhouse gases that are released from the landfill.  diverting waste saves money spent on collecting and disposing of garbage, and allows the economic value of organic waste, and usable or recyclable materials to be recovered. the percentage of waste from surrey citizens that is diverted is a measure of how well residents reduce their waste.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/communitywaste).

groups.description: the city of surrey is committed to protecting and enhancing natural and environmentally sensitive areas from harmful development. policies and regulations with respect to environmentally sensitive development are contained in city plans and by-laws as well as in provincial and federal acts.
groups.name: environment

construction waste.name: construction waste
construction waste.notes:
waste from construction, demolition, and renovation makes up a significant portion of the municipality's waste stream. more than half of wastes generated by construction and demolition are recyclable and can be diverted. reducing construction waste reduces environmental impact and saves money for the industry, as tipping fees for separated recyclables are much lower than mixed waste loads. the percentage of construction wastes that are diverted is a measure of how well industry is doing at reducing waste and its environmental footprint. data source: metro vancouver.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#water_and_waste/constructionwaste).

groups.description: a diverse collection of datasets that are equally important but do not belong to a themed group.
groups.name: miscellaneous

core housing need.name: core housing need
core housing need.notes:
core housing need is when individuals are living in housing that requires major repair, does not have enough space for the needs of the household, or costs 30% or more of the household's income. these situations can be financially draining, unhealthy and stressful for individuals and families.  the percentage of renter households in core housing need is a measure of the need for adequate, appropriate and affordable housing in surrey. the city aims to see a downward trend in the proportion of individuals in core housing need. data source: statistics canada (note: 2011 data quality may be inferior to previous years due to the voluntary nature of the national household survey that has replaced the mandatory long form census).

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/corehousing).

corporate greenhouse gas emissions.name: corporate greenhouse gas emissions
corporate greenhouse gas emissions.notes:
the city is committed to fighting climate change, which begins with leadership in our own operations. building higher energy performance buildings, retrofitting existing facilities to be more efficient, investing in low-emission fleet vehicles, and leading the way with innovative technologies are just a few of the ways we've been taking action. reducing energy use is also an important strategy for reducing costs, particularly as city facilities expand to keep pace with growth. the ghg emissions from the city's corporate operations is a measure of how well the city is doing to improve energy efficiency and reduce its impact on climate change. the city's target is a 20% reduction in ghg emissions from operations by 2020.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/corporate_ghg).

groups.description: a local council authority that provides local services, facilities, safety and infrastructure for communities. while the municipality has autonomy on most decisions, all by-laws passed are subject to change by the provincial government at any time.
groups.name: local-government

council expense reports.name: council expense reports
council expense reports.notes: council member expenses incurred while conducting business on behalf of the city.

council records documents.name: council records documents
council records documents.notes:
links to current city council meeting minutes, agendas, action items.

##meeting schedules##
you're invited to attend council meetings held monday evenings at surrey city hall. council meetings are held in the council chambers and are simultaneously [live streamed on our website.](http://www.surrey.ca/city-government/6993.aspx)

videos of recent meetings are archived and available for viewing [here.](http://www.surrey.ca/city-government/6993.aspx)

[__2017 council meeting schedule__](http://www.surrey.ca/bylawsandcouncillibrary/dct_council_meeting_schedule_2017.pdf)

[__2018 council meeting schedule__](http://www.surrey.ca/bylawsandcouncillibrary/dct_council_meeting_schedule_2018.pdf)

##council minutes##
the first surrey municipality council meeting was held on january 12, 1880.  the minutes from that meeting onwards are all available online. 

early historical minutes have been scanned and although the contents cannot always be searched through normal keyword methods, they provide a colourful history of our past and are well worth viewing.

[__regular council, land use & public hearing__](http://www.surrey.ca/city-government/5515.aspx)

[__council-in-committee__](http://www.surrey.ca/city-government/5492.aspx)

##action items##
action items provide a draft summary of the most recent council meetings.  although the minutes of the meetings will not be adopted until the next meeting, the public may review the decisions that have been made.  action pages are posted in draft form by legislative services within 24 hours of a meeting.

[__regular council -  land use__](http://www.surrey.ca/bylawsandcouncillibrary/act_rclu_current.pdf)

[__regular council - public hearing__](http://www.surrey.ca/bylawsandcouncillibrary/act_rcph_current.pdf)

[__regular council__](http://www.surrey.ca/bylawsandcouncillibrary/act_rc_current.pdf)

if you need to reference corporate reports, planning reports or public notices found in these action pages, please visit our [electronic council library.](http://www.surrey.ca/city-government/4871.aspx)

cpted certified development.name: cpted certified development
cpted certified development.notes:
crime prevention through environmental design (c.p.t.e.d.) is a set of strategies that can pro-actively deter crime. it emphasises the use of design features to decrease the opportunity for crime to take place. strategies include creating open spaces that maximise visibility and observation, and making street life open and inviting for residents. the number of major new developments that undergo a crime prevention review via the city's advisory design panel is a measure of how well spaces in surrey promote public safety.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_and_safety/cpted).

crime rate.name: crime rate
crime rate.notes:
protecting people and property is a priority under surrey’s public safety strategy, and is important for ensuring a high quality of life for people who live and work in the community. preventing and reducing crime in surrey involves effective enforcement, timely response, and the collaborative efforts of community organizations and criminal justice professionals. the crime severity index is a metric that looks at annual crime rates, and weights police-reported incidents according to the seriousness of the offense.  it is based on criminal code incidents, including traffic offences, as well as other federal statute violations. the crime severity index helps provide a more nuanced understanding of the relative severity or seriousness of crime in a community and allows us to see whether serious crime is increasing or decreasing over time. surrey aims to see a decline in the crime severity index over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#public_safety/crimerate).

groups.description: the city of surrey is responsible for the encouragement, regulation and enforcement of workplace health, safety and welfare. residents and families are encouraged to maintain an active and healthy lifestyle and have the ability to attend both registered and drop-in programs.
groups.name: health-and-safety

criminal offences.name: criminal offences
criminal offences.notes:
criminal code offences include violent crimes (e.g. robbery, assault) and property crimes (e.g. theft, shoplifting, arson) and others (e.g. causing a disturbance). criminal code offences can cause pain and suffering and lower the quality of life of victims and their communities and drives up security costs. reducing these offences promotes safer and healthier individuals and communities and reduces property and insurance costs. the number of criminal code offences is a measure of public safety in surrey. the city aims to see a downward trend in crime. data source: surrey rcmp.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_and_safety/criminaloffenses).

groups.description: each community offers a diverse range of recreational spaces including gymnasiums, preschool sites, fitness studios, weight rooms, pools and outdoor spaces. the city of surrey offers registered and drop-in recreational activities to keep its residents healthy, active and engaged.

cultural businesses.name: cultural businesses
cultural businesses.notes:
cultural activities are recognized as an important way for individuals to contribute to their communities. culture is an essential tool in understanding the values, shared meanings, and goals of residents within a community. the arts, culture and sports industries are economic drivers in the community that support jobs, generate revenue, and support tourism. the number of cultural businesses in surrey is a measure of the viability and vibrancy of cultural industries in surrey. the city aims to see an upward trend in cultural businesses as the population increases.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#arts_culture_events/culturalbusiness)

groups.description: each community offers a diverse range of recreational spaces including gymnasiums, preschool sites, fitness studios, weight rooms, pools and outdoor spaces. the city of surrey offers registered and drop-in recreational activities to keep its residents healthy, active and engaged.

cultural spaces.name: cultural spaces
cultural spaces.notes:
cultural activities are recognized as an important way for individuals to contribute to their communities. culture is an essential tool in understanding the values, shared meanings, and goals of residents within a community. cultural spaces offer opportunities for residents to learn about the social and ecological heritages of the communities where they live. the square footage of cultural space is a measure of availability of cultural learning opportunities in surrey. the city aims to see an upward trend in cultural spaces over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#arts_culture_events/culturalspaces)

current smokers.name: current smokers
current smokers.notes:
smoking is widely recognized to have negative effects on health and is the single most preventable cause of ill health and death. the average smoker has a life expectancy that is eight years shorter than an average non-smoker. smoking is related to many diseases and conditions, including heart problems and various cancers. smoking also has serious health risks for non-smokers that are exposed to secondhand smoke. the proportion of the population that currently smokes is a measure of how healthy surrey residents are. the city aims to see a downward trend, with levels continuing to be below the bc average. data source: statistics canada.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_wellness/current_smokers).

groups.name: transportation

density on transit corridors.name: density on transit corridors
density on transit corridors.notes:
locating residential and commercial developments adjacent to transit corridors helps to increase transit ridership and support better transit service. transit-oriented developments tend to be mixed-use, with shops, schools, and other public services conveniently located close together. compact communities help protect green spaces and farm land by easing development pressure. population and employment density on transit corridors is a measure of how compact and complete surrey's communities are, and the city aims to see increases in density over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#built_environment/transitcorridors)

drainage 200 year flood plain.notes:
the area that can be expected to flood, on average, once every 200 years. this is called the 200-year flood and can occur at any time in any given year. the indicated flood limit may be exceeded and portions of the floodplain can flood more frequently. the delineation of the flood plain is estimated by the bc ministry of sustainable resource management and the drainage section of the city of surrey. updates are made whenever possible & modeled.

drainage detention ponds.name: drainage detention ponds
drainage detention ponds.notes:
a man-made pond providing storage of stormwater drainage in order to control the rate of outflow or discharge. the pond can be "wet" where a minimum depth of water is maintained year round or "dry" where the pond is empty between rainstorms and can function as open spaces for other uses. these point features contain all the relevant attribute information for detention ponds. detention pond boundaries have been removed from the drainage dataset.

drainage devices.name: drainage devices
drainage devices.notes: devices are complex objects that do not fall under manholes. these can be grated openings to collect surface runoff, including roadside catch basins and lawn drains. this layer also includes inspection chambers (circular 200 mm to 600 mm diameter chambers, installed within the drainage service connection pipe at or near the property line to allow inspection of the drainage connection pipe between the building foundation drain and the city’s storm sewer pipe). other devices that control flow include flow control (control manholes), sea dam, and energy dissipater.

drinking water quality.name: drinking water quality
drinking water quality.notes:
in metro vancouver, water is collected from rainfall, snowmelt, creeks, and streams from the mountains near the capilano, seymour and coquitlam watersheds. our drinking water comes from one of the most pristine water sources in the world, and we are fortunate to have access to safe and reliable water each time we turn on the tap. metro vancouver and the city of surrey closely monitor water quality throughout the system of reservoirs, treatment plants, pump stations, and water mains. residents and businesses play an important role in protecting our drinking water by preventing backflow and contamination from other substances. the percentage of drinking water tests that meet water quality guidelines is a measure of how safe and clean our water supply is.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/drinking_water_quality).

groups.name: miscellaneous

early childhood development.name: early childhood development
early childhood development.notes:
children that have not had secure, nurturing, and stimulating experiences in their early years are at higher risk of many challenges later on in life, including mental health problems, obesity, heart disease, and criminality. the early development instrument (e.d.i.) measures childhood vulnerability along 5 scales: physical health and well being; social competence; emotional maturity; language and cognitive development; communication and general knowledge. the percentage of children that are vulnerable in at least one scale of the e.d.i. is a measure of population health, and the city aims to see a 15% reduction in this number by 2015. data source: ubc's human early learning partnership.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/childhood_development).

employees by sector.name: employees by sector
employees by sector.notes:
the number of employees in all sectors is essential to understanding economic activity in surrey. analyzing shifts and changes over time can assist the city in continuing to build the education and skill profile of surrey's workforce. it can also help with identifying possible skills shortages or over supply in the labour force. the number of employees in all sectors of surrey's economy is a measure of economic activity and performance in the city.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/employees)

employment in arts culture and recreatio.name: employment in arts culture and recreation
employment in arts culture and recreatio.notes:
culture is an essential tool in understanding the values, shared meanings, and goals of residents within a community. the arts, culture and sports industries are economic drivers in the community that support jobs, generate revenue, and support tourism. the proportion of surrey's workforce that is employed in arts, culture, recreation, or sports is a measure of the viability and vibrancy of cultural industries in surrey. the city aims to see the proportion of people employed in the arts, culture and recreation trend up over time. data source: statistics canada (note: 2011 data quality may be inferior to previous years due to the voluntary nature of the national household survey that has replaced the mandatory long form census).

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/artsemployment)

facilities that offer city programs.notes:
programs and services are essential to people's lives. recreation, sport, and arts and cultural services allow people of all ages to learn new skills, meet new people, develop positive interests, and become involved in the community. even distribution of services and amenities throughout the city ensures that every resident has equal access. the availability of facilities that offer programs is a measure of how evenly distributed services are in the city of surrey.

farm receipts.notes:
farming is a key contributor to the economic base of the community. farming in surrey provides income to farm businesses, generates significant economic activity, and provides local jobs. the agriculture sector needs to be viable and thriving in order to continue providing economic benefits. farm receipts are a measure of the economic viability and performance of the agriculture sector. data source: statistics canada.

fraser health restaurant inspection repo.name: fraser health restaurant inspection reports
fraser health restaurant inspection repo.notes:
inspections are conducted on a routine basis and when complaints are received. inspections determine if regulatory requirements and industry standard practices are being followed with respect to general food handling, storage temperatures, sanitation, employee hygiene and procedures for cleaning and/or sanitizing equipment or food contact surfaces.

each visit generates an inspection report that is provided to the operator to either confirm that they are compliant with regulations, or to inform them that they are required to address deficiencies.

for more information please visit the [fraser health](http://www.fraserhealth.ca/health-info/health-topics/food-safety/restaurant-inspections/) website.

*please note: this dataset will only give you the results of the fraser health inspection reports. there is a related dataset called [restaurants](http://data.surrey.ca/dataset/restaurants) that has restaurant information extracted from the fraser health inspection data with the latitude and longitude values added by the city of surrey gis section. you can spatially enable this inspection reports dataset by joining it to the restaurants dataset via the "trackingnumber" attribute.

gov investments community infrastructure.name: gov investments community infrastructure
gov investments community infrastructure.notes:
community infrastructure is the system of facilities that offer opportunities for education, employment, recreation and social inclusion. these physical assets, along with the services, programs, and activities that they house and enable, are the foundation of strong and healthy neighbourhoods. community infrastructure can be passive, such as parks and trails, or be active, such as art and cultural centres that offer programs and classes. the investments in community infrastructure is a measure of how well community infrastructure is supported, and the city aims to see increasing investment from senior governments over the long term.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#growth/communityinfrastructure)

groups.description: the city of surrey is responsible for the encouragement, regulation and enforcement of workplace health, safety and welfare. residents and families are encouraged to maintain an active and healthy lifestyle and have the ability to attend both registered and drop-in programs.
groups.name: health-and-safety

graffiti reports.name: graffiti reports
graffiti reports.notes:
graffiti refers to images and lettering painted, scratched, or marked on property, that is inscribed without the property owner's permission. graffiti is sometimes used to express social and political messages and, depending on the situation and context, can be a form of art. the number of graffiti report files is a measure of unwelcome graffiti activity in surrey, and the city aims to see a downward trend over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_and_safety/graffiti).

groups.description: the city of surrey is committed to protecting and enhancing natural and environmentally sensitive areas from harmful development. policies and regulations with respect to environmentally sensitive development are contained in city plans and by-laws as well as in provincial and federal acts.

green infrastructure network.name: green infrastructure network
green infrastructure network.notes:
a green infrastructure network (gin) is an interconnected system of natural areas and open spaces that conserves ecosystems and functions, while providing benefits to both wildlife and people. defined in surrey’s biodiversity conservation strategy (bcs), the gin is composed of 3,885 hectares (ha) of land consisting of urban ecosystems and  habitat corridors, sites and hubs providing a range of crucial ecosystem services. when the bcs was adopted, about 70% of the lands identified were already under public ownership (such as city, provincial, regional or federal), including 2,019 ha of city-owned park land. this leaves approximately 1,215 ha of private lands to be purchased or stewarded. the amount of gin land protected and stewarded is a measure of how well the city is doing to preserve and enhance natural habitats and biodiversity. the city aims to manage 100% of the gin over time through public ownership and third party stewardship programs on private land.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#ecosystems/vegetativecover)

[view in cosmos](http://cosmos.surrey.ca/external/?showlayers=green%20infrastructure%20network%20corridors,green%20infrastructure%20network%20hubs%20and%20sites,green%20infrastructure%20areas&layername=green%20infrastructure%20network%20corridors)

healthy food choices in city vending mac.notes:
healthy and nutritious food choices must be available for people to maintain a balanced diet. "health check", a not-for-profit food information program run by the heart and stroke foundation, labels food products and menu items that meet specific nutrient standards based on canada's food guide. the percentage of "health check" choices in city vending machines is a measure of how available healthy and nutritious food choices are.

heritage sites.name: heritage sites
heritage sites.notes:
heritage sites are locations having specific heritage status and included on the surrey heritage register.

heritage is what we inherit from the past, value in the present, and plan to preserve for the future. surrey's heritage includes the natural ecosystems, first nations people, and settlers from many cultures that logged the forests and established farms and communities. heritage helps to define our unique character and image and is an important component of creating community pride and identity. the number of protected heritage sites in surrey is a measure of how well natural and built history are being conserved.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/heritagesites).

[view in cosmos](http://cosmos.surrey.ca/external/new/cosmos.html?showlayers=heritage%20sites&layername=heritage%20sites)

groups.name: miscellaneous

high school graduation.name: high school graduation
high school graduation.notes:
education enables individuals to be more competitive in the job market, have better job opportunities, and have higher earnings. high school completion sends a strong signal to prospective employers and is often necessary for obtaining post-secondary education. students that do not complete high school have a more difficult time finding work and can face barriers to pursuing further training and learning. the high school completion rate is a measure of educational attainment of high school students in surrey, and the city aims to see a 2% increase in graduation rates per decade. data source: bc ministry of education.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/highschoolgraduation).

homelessness.name: homelessness
homelessness.notes:
people are homeless when they do not have housing or rely on couch-surfing with family and friends. homelessness happens for many reasons, including challenges with physical disability, mental illness, addiction, or the ability to find adequate employment.  the number of homeless people in surrey is a measure of the size of the homelessness problem and community need for affordable housing, adequate income, and access to health and social support services. the city aims to end homelessness by 2032. data source: metro vancouver regional steering committee on homelessness.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/homelessness).

important trees.notes:
maintained by: parks division (public property trees); planning (private property trees) description: important trees are those trees that have been set aside as examples of significant trees under surrey's tree preservation by-law and/or listed on surrey's heritage register and/or identified by the heritage advisory commission.

groups.name: health-and-safety

incidences of break enters.name: incidences of break enters
incidences of break enters.notes:
break-and-enter offences have social effects and economic costs. it can cause pain and suffering, a sense of insecurity, financial loss, and a lower quality of life to victims and their communities. reducing break-and-enter incidences promotes safer communities, reduced property and insurance costs, and less burden on the criminal justice system.  the number of break-and-enter offences is a measure of public safety and security in surrey, and the city aims to see a downward trend in incidences over time. data source: surrey rcmp.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_and_safety/breakin_enter).

groups.description: the economic development and sustainability office collect and analyze information to make investment decisions, encourage business growth and create municipal economic policy. such information include economic indicators, business licensing statistics, demographic profiles and building permits.
groups.name: business-and-economy

individuals and families with low income.name: individuals and families with low income
individuals and families with low income.notes:
individuals with low income have inadequate resources for basic needs, maintaining a healthy standard of living, and enabling a sense of security and full participation in society. low income and poverty are consistently linked to poorer health, more stress on family members, greater reliance on community and social services, and diminished school success. the rate of low income individuals is a measure of surrey's overall social and economic well-being, and the city aims to see a downward trend over time. (data source: statistics canada. note: 2011 data quality may be inferior to previous years due to the voluntary nature of the national household survey that has replaced the mandatory long form census, and the use of the low-income measure-after tax (lim-at) that has replaced the low income cut off (lico)).

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/lowincome)

groups.name: land-use-and-development

industrial land base.name: industrial land base
industrial land base.notes:
as land value increase over time, areas zoned for industrial use face pressure from commercial and residential development. many businesses, such as warehousing and water-borne industries, that are critical components of the surrey and metro vancouver economies require industrial land. maintaining an industrial land base supports these businesses and jobs. it also generates revenue for the city and contributes to a more diversified tax base. the industrial land base indicator is a measure of how well the city is doing in maintaining its supply of industrial land. (note: surrey's official community plan, which came into effect in 2014, includes the "industrial" and "mixed employment" designations to protect industrial land.)

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/industrial).

groups.description: the city of surrey is committed to protecting and enhancing natural and environmentally sensitive areas from harmful development. policies and regulations with respect to environmentally sensitive development are contained in city plans and by-laws as well as in provincial and federal acts.
groups.name: environment

integrated stormwater management plans.name: integrated stormwater management plans
integrated stormwater management plans.notes: integrated stormwater management plans (ismps) take an ecosystem-based approach to rainwater management. these plans are an essential part of a city's growth management strategy since land use changes can increase flood and environmental risks. an ismp is specific to an individual watershed and outlines recommendations to address existing and potential drainage, erosion, and flooding concerns, protect and restore stream health, and improve existing or potential water quality problems. the percent of surrey's land area that is covered by an ismp is a measure of how well surrey is managing stormwater in the city.

internet connectivity.name: internet connectivity
internet connectivity.notes:
internet connectivity is increasingly important in today's world. for businesses and individuals, the internet provides a platform to both access and distribute information and services. it is an important communications tool, and has been called by the united nations "an enabler of human rights, [which] boosts economic, social and political development". internet connectivity is a measure of how many surrey residents are able to access the internet from home, and the city aims to see an upward trend over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/connectivity).

groups.description: the economic development and sustainability office collect and analyze information to make investment decisions, encourage business growth and create municipal economic policy. such information include economic indicators, business licensing statistics, demographic profiles and building permits.
groups.name: business-and-economy

land in food production.name: land in food production
land in food production.notes:
approximately one-third of surrey's land base is agricultural land, consisting of about 10,000 hectares of lowlands surrounding the serpentine, the nicomekl, and the campbell rivers. at any given time, however, not all land will be in use, and some land will be used for non-food producing purposes, such as fodder for horses. the amount of total farmland (inside and outside the agricultural land reserve) that is used to produce food is a measure of surrey's capacity to produce food locally, and it is the city's policy to see no net loss of agricultural land being used for food production over time. data source: statistics canada.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/landinfoodproduction).

leisure access pass participants.notes:
recreation and leisure helps to improve physical fitness, reduce stress, and contribute to general well-being. ensuring that residents with low-income have access to city programs helps to ensure that all residents have equal opportunities to enjoy and benefit from recreation, leisure, and arts services. the proportion of low income individuals registered in the l.a.p. program is a measure of how available recreation, sport, and arts opportunities are to residents with financial barriers to access.

licensed childcare.name: licensed childcare
licensed childcare.notes:
high quality childcare supports healthy childhood development by helping children to learn and develop strong physical, social, emotional, intellectual, and language skills. access to child care is particularly important for single or working parents. the availability of licensed child care is a measure of how accessible child care resources are to surrey residents. the city aims to see an upward trend, bringing the number of child care spaces closer in line to the number of children in surrey. data source: fraser health.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/licensed_childcare).

low birth weight babies.name: low birth weight babies
low birth weight babies.notes:
low birth weight is an important factor that influences infant survival, health and development. babies that weigh less than 2,500 grams at birth have increased chances of experiencing health problems, slower development, and even premature death. babies may have low birth weight if they are born prematurely or are too small for their gestational age. the percentage of low birth weight babies is a measure of infant health, and the city aims to see a downward trend over time. data source: bc vital statistics.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_and_safety/lowbirthweight).

median household income.notes:
individuals with low income have inadequate resources for basic needs, maintaining a healthy standard of living, and enabling a sense of security and full participation in society. low income and poverty are consistently linked to poorer health, more stress on family members, greater reliance on community and social services, and diminished school success. the rate of low income individuals is a measure of surrey's overall social and economic well-being, and the city aims to see a downward trend over time. groups.name: business-and-economy

median income for immigrants.name: median income for immigrants
median income for immigrants.notes:
immigrants to canada generally have lower incomes than canadian-born residents when they first arrive. over time, they become more established and eventually catch up to their canadian-born counterparts. in recent years, the time that it takes for immigrants to become established is taking longer, resulting in lower income as compared to canadian-born residents. the median income of immigrants is a measure of the economic and social well-being of surrey's immigrant population, and the city's aim is that it equals that of the total population over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#inclusion/immigrantincome).

groups.name: transportation

medians.name: medians
medians.notes: polygon representations of raised medians within surrey. these do not include painted medians, (see pavement markings). median subtypes are defined as: central - a raised concrete median dividing a road island - includes all raised medians not dividing the centre of a road. this includes turning lane islands, cul-de-sac islands and pork chop medians planter - raised concrete planter boxes, usually located on either side of speed tables or speed humps.

groups.name: transportation

mode of travel to work.name: mode of travel to work
mode of travel to work.notes:
transportation accounts for a large portion of greenhouse gas emissions in the province, with vehicles also contributing to traffic congestion, local air pollution and smog.  taking transit, walking, cycling, and carpooling are ways of getting around that have lower environmental impact, release fewer greenhouse gas emissions, have more health benefits, and contribute to cleaner and healthier communities.  modal share of travel to work is a measure of how sustainable our travel patterns are. data sources: translink trip diaries and statistics canada (note: 2011 data quality may be inferior to previous years due to the voluntary nature of the national household survey that has replaced the mandatory long form census).

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#infrastructure/mode_of_travel).

multi family housing.name: multi family housing
multi family housing.notes:
multi-family housing is a type of housing where several residential units are located in one building. the most common form of multi-family housing is the apartment building. multi-family housing serves a variety of lifestyle needs and income levels. it can often be more affordable, energy efficient, easier to maintain and more convenient in terms of location and transportation than single-family housing.  the percentage of new housing starts in surrey that are multi-family dwellings is a measure of the diversity of housing stock and choices in the city.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#housing/multifamily).

municipal revenues.name: municipal revenues
municipal revenues.notes:
the intent of this report is to provide council with an update on the city’s financial activity for the
second quarter of 2016 and to compare this activity with the adopted 2016 financial plan and the
same period in 2015. this report will also provide council with an update on additional grants that
have been approved by the city to various organizations since the 2016 community grant program
was approved; these are specifically in relation to the city’s community enhancement partnership
(cep) program, late community grants and the façade enhancement program.

neighbourhood enhancement grants.notes:

park land.name: park land
park land.notes:
parks contribute to public health by providing places for recreation, exercise, and leisure. studies show that when people have access to parks, they tend to get more exercise. exposure to natural landscapes and greenery also contributes to psychological health. vegetation in parks offer environmental benefits by reducing air and water pollution, providing habitat, keeping temperatures cooler, and managing stormwater run-off. the city aims to see an upward trend in parkland over time.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#ecosystems/parkland).

participation environmental programs.name: participation environmental programs
participation environmental programs.notes:
environmental programs educate children, youth, and adults on how natural systems function and how they can take action to protect wildlife, maintain environmental quality, and live sustainably. environmental programs raise awareness, promote an ethic of stewardship, and help to restore and care for precious environmental assets and features in the community. the number of participants in environmental programs run and sponsored by the city is a measure of environmental awareness among surrey residents.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#ecosystems/environmentalprograms).

groups.description: there are a variety of local community services, agencies, organization and information offered by both the city of surrey and outside organizations. these services provide the building blocks of creating a strong and healthy community.
groups.name: community-services

groups.description: a local council authority that provides local services, facilities, safety and infrastructure for communities. while the municipality has autonomy on most decisions, all by-laws passed are subject to change by the provincial government at any time.
groups.name: local-government

participation in city programs.name: participation in city programs
participation in city programs.notes:
recreation, sports, and arts programs are vital to development of children and youth and to building healthy communities. programs allow people of all ages to learn new skills, meet new people, develop positive interests, and become involved in the community. recreation and leisure helps to improve physical fitness, reduce stress, and contribute to general well-being. the number of visits to programs offered by the city is a measure of how available and well-used recreation, sport, and arts opportunities are to surrey citizens.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#health_wellness/cityprograms)

participation in emergency preparedness.name: participation in emergency preparedness program
participation in emergency preparedness.notes:
whether it is an earthquake, flood, power outage or other emergency, residents and businesses should be prepared for unexpected events and disasters. creating an emergency kit, knowing what to do in an evacuation, developing a plan with your neighbours, and considering business continuity will help our community be more resilient. as climate change increases the likelihood of natural disasters, ensuring the public is prepared is even more critical. the number of residents who have participated in surrey's personal and neighbourhood emergency preparedness programs is a measure of how prepared and resilient the public is to handle a disasater.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#public_safety/preparedness).

groups.description: there are a variety of local community services, agencies, organization and information offered by both the city of surrey and outside organizations. these services provide the building blocks of creating a strong and healthy community.
groups.name: community-services

participation in the harvest box program.name: participation in the harvest box program
participation in the harvest box program.notes:
the harvest box program is a fresh produce bulk buying program that offers fresh produce at affordable prices. the program supports local farmers and serves families in surrey, langley, delta, and white rock. the level of participation in the program is a measure of how many families consume fresh fruits and vegetables, an essential part of a nutritious diet. it is also a measure of food security in surrey. 

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#food/harvestbox).

pay parking stations.notes:

[view in cosmos](http://cosmos.surrey.ca/external/new/cosmos.html?showlayers=pay%20parking%20stations&layername=pay%20parking%20stations)

groups.description: the finance department provides financial expertise, advice and guidance to support city operations. they provide responsive service to their clients, leadership in improving city processes and maintain financial practices, policies and standards while supporting the city's sustainability charter.
groups.name: finance

payments to suppliers for goods and serv.name: payments to suppliers for goods and services
payments to suppliers for goods and serv.notes:
regulations require the city of surrey to report the total amount paid to each supplier for goods 
and services that exceeds $25,000 in the year reported.

this data is part of the statement of financial information (sofi).  for more information please see the [sofi reports](http://www.surrey.ca/city-government/6511.aspx).

pedestrian and bicycle collisions.name: pedestrian and bicycle collisions
pedestrian and bicycle collisions.notes:
cycling and walking are important modes of transportation for maintaining health, reducing our environmental impact, and creating a vibrant community. ensuring our streets are safe for pedestrians and cyclists of all abilities is necessary if we want to help people walk and cycle more in their daily lives. the number of bicycle and pedestrian incidents per year is a measure of how safe our streets are for these vulnerable road users.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#public_safety/collisions).

groups.description: the transportation department provides transportation options in surrey regarding driving, cycling, walking, taking transit or finding a new smarter travel choice. surrey's [transportation strategic plan] (http://www.surrey.ca/city-services/4789.aspx) shows the vision, goals, proposals and priorities for transportation in the city.
groups.name: transportation

place of work.name: place of work
place of work.notes:
compact and complete communities provide opportunities for residents to work close to home. local jobs can make walking, cycling and taking transit to work more attractive options, resulting in cleaner and healthier communities, fewer cars on the road, and reduced greenhouse gas emissions. the comparison between the percentage of residents that live and work in the same community to those who live locally but work elsewhere is a measure of a complete community. data source: statistics canada (note: 2011 data quality may be inferior to previous years due to the voluntary nature of the national household survey that has replaced the mandatory long form census).

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#economy/placeofwork).

pocket markets.name: pocket markets
pocket markets.notes:
pocket markets enhance community food security by bringing fresh local produce to urban residents and supporting local farm businesses. pocket markets are essentially 'mini farmer's markets': one time events, in which a number of local farmers are able to sell their produce directly to residents. the number of pocket markets is a measure of food security in surrey. data sources: surrey urban farmers market, surrey/white rock food action coalition.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#food/pocketmarkets).

post secondary certification.name: post secondary certification
post secondary certification.notes:
post-secondary education includes academic undergraduate and postgraduate degree programs; vocational, career, and technical certificate programs; apprenticeship programs in designated trades; and entry level trades training certificate programs. individuals with post-secondary certification are more competitive in the job market, have better job opportunities, and have higher earnings than a high school graduate. the percentage of surrey's population that has achieved post-secondary certification is a measure of post-secondary educational achievement. data source: statistics canada (note: 2011 data quality may be inferior to previous years due to the voluntary nature of the national household survey that has replaced the mandatory long form census).

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/postsecondary_certification).

groups.name: business-and-economy

post secondary enrolment.name: post secondary enrolment
post secondary enrolment.notes:
individuals with post-secondary education are more competitive in the job market, have better job opportunities, and have higher earnings than a high school graduate. the number of enrolled undergraduate students is a measure of educational attainment, and the city aims to see an upward trend over time. data sources: simon fraser university and kwantlen polytechnic university.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#education_culture/postsecondary_enrolment).

proximity of homes to amenities.name: proximity of homes to amenities
proximity of homes to amenities.notes:
the degree to which residential units are in proximity to amenities is a measure of how liveable surrey's neighbourhoods are. all households need access to amenities such as grocery stores, retail and parks, and many households desire to be close to transit and schools. being within a short walk (generally 400 meters) of amenities increases the likelihood and convenience of using them and encourages residents to get more daily exercise, save money on gas and car maintenance, and reduce their environmental impact.

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#built_environment/proximity_amenities)

groups.description: a diverse collection of datasets that are equally important but do not belong to a themed group.
groups.name: miscellaneous

proximity to farmers markets.name: proximity to farmers markets
proximity to farmers markets.notes:
farmers markets enhance community food security by giving farmers direct access to customers, and enabling residents to buy fresh, local produce. it also provides residents the opportunity to learn more about where their food comes from and meet the people that grew it. locating farmers markets within a short walk, cycle, or transit ride of residents makes them easily and conveniently accessible, which is a measure of food security. the city aims to see 75% of the population living within a 20 minute bike ride (6.6 km) of a farmer's market by 2058. 

see this and other sustainability indicators on the city's [sustainability dashboard](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#food/farmersmarkets).

public art.name: public art
public art.notes: surrey's public art program brings thoughtful and playful art into the city, from mosaics and paintings to contemporary illuminated sculptures. the growing collection of artworks enrich parks, pathways, skytrain pillars, and civic buildings.  for additional information please visit [surrey public art](http://www.surrey.ca/culture-recreation/1650.aspx "here").

public meetings.name: public meetings
public meetings.notes:
the health and development of all aspects of a community is the responsibility of citizens as well as that of government and industry. citizens involvement in municipal decisions and plans can provide valuable feedback for city staff, create broad-based support for projects and initiatives, identify community needs, and contribute to a more inclusive and democratic city. the number of public meetings organized by the city clerk's office (e.g. council meetings, advisory committee meetings) is a measure of the public's access to decision-making, and the city aims to see an upward trend over time.

for this and other sustainability indicators, see the city's [sustainability dashboard.](http://dashboard.surrey.ca/#government/publicmeetings)

rainfall monitoring.name: rainfall monitoring
rainfall monitoring.notes: provides concise rainfall statistics from the city of surrey's six rain gauge stations. rainfall levels are recorded at 5 minute intervals and are presented in monthly tables for the year 2018. all measurements are in millimeters. for information on comparing rainfall summaries between the current and previous month, please see the city's [rainfall monitoring site](http://www.flowworks.com/network/hmiscreens/surrey/surreyrain.aspx).  to preview or download the spatial locations of surrey's rain gauges, please see the [monitoring stations](http://data.surrey.ca/dataset/drainage-monitoring-stations) section. for previous years datasets please visit the archive page [here](http://data.surrey.ca/dataset/rainfall-monitoring-archive).
